lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/count.Count.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run count.Count.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
## How do I install and run Count?
1: Download Count.jar from the releases page
2: Navigate to the directory containing the JAR file (Optional: make a new directory for it)
3: Run the jar file with the following command
1: Download Count.jar from the releases page
2: Place it in a folder (This is where your tasks will be saved and loaded from)
Check that you have Java installed in order to use Count!
Welcome to Count, your new digital assistant here to help streamline your day!
Now with innovative functions such as a built-in task list, you can effortlessly manage and track your tasks and deadlines,
ensuring nothing slips through the cracks.
This readme serves as the documentation guide for how to talk to Count Borg!
But you could always just ask the amphibian himself.
10.'remind': Reminds the user what tasks are due in within the specified number of days.
A to-do task would be a non-pressing task with no fixed due date.
An example would be something basic like, buy bread for a snack
Template: `todo buy bread for a snack`
Count Borg will then add it to your task list!
You now have 1 task(s) in your list
A deadline task as it's name suggests, has a do-by-date.
An example would be something like, homework due on 20th October 2024
You now have 2 task(s) in your list
An Event task is one that runs from a start time, to an end time.
An example would be something like,
a holiday overseas from 10th September 2024 to 17th September 2024
You now have 3 task(s) in your list
## Seeing what is on the Task List
To view all tasks added to Count, it's as simple as just asking!
Here are the tasks in your list:
Done with a task? Mark it as done!
For example, if you are done buying bread...
Ribbit, I have marked this task as complete:
For example, if you mistakenly marked buying bread as complete...
Ribbit, I have marked this task as incomplete:
## Save Tasks as a text file
Want to manually save your tasks?
Save your task list as a text file right next to the application.
Ribbit, your list has been saved over at Count.txt
## Load Tasks from a text file
To view a task list, it's as simple as dropping it off next to the Count.jar
Opening the application will load it right up as long as it is in the correct format!
Too much stuff on your plate? Sift through your task list using keywords with find!
Ribbit, here are the matching tasks in your list
Similarly, if you want to know what Deadlines and Events are due in n days, you can use remind
Finds all Deadlines and Events due within 7 days
For example, if today is September 10, 2024. Inputting "remind 7" will yield:
Here are the tasks due within 7 days
Here are the tasks due within 50 days

* Else it is a single word, it passes the whole command to singleWordParser

* The TaskList class stores the ArrayList<Task>
* allowing it to be passed by reference
* Constructs TaskList object if no ArrayList<Task> is provided
* Constructs TaskList object if an ArrayList<Task> is provided
* The abstract Action class acts as a blueprint for all commands
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException for any child to throw children of CountException
public abstract String run() throws CountException;
* The AddTask class is used to add tasks to the TaskList
* @param ls TaskList to add the task into
* @param t Task to add into the TaskList
* Adds the object's Task to the object's TaskList
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return "Ribbit, added the following task:\n" + this.task.toString()
+ "\nYou now have " + ls.getTaskList().size() + " task(s) in your list";
* The Deactivate class is used to turn the Count program off
* Returns the String for Count's UI to print
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return "Bye. Hope to see you again soon!";
* The Delete class is used to delete tasks to the TaskList
* @param ls TaskList to delete the task from
* @param index int index of the Task in TaskList to delete
* Deletes the Task with the index of index from TaskList
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the index selected is out of bounds for the TaskList
return "Ribbit, I have removed this task from the list:\n"
+ taskRemoved.toString() + "\nYou now have " + ls.getTaskList().size() + " task(s) in your list";
throw new CountException("Croak! Invalid list index chosen! Choose a number from 1 to "
+ ls.getTaskList().size() + "\nType 'help' to see correct formatting examples");

* Finds all Tasks containing the given key
* appending it to the return String
* @return String for Count's UI to print
String ans = "Ribbit, here are the matching tasks in your list\n";
return "Croak! There are no matching tasks in your list\n";
* The Greet class is used to give a welcome message
* Returns the String for Count's UI to print
* @return String for Count's UI to print
return "Hello! I'm Count Borg!\nWhat can I do for you?";
* The Help class is used to give a message on how to format commands
* Returns the String for Count's UI to print
* @return String for Count's UI to print

+ "

3.'list': Lists all tasks added in the order that they were added in
 Usecase: list"

+ "

4.'todo': Adds a task with no date or time attached
 Usecase: todo bake bread"

+ "

5.'deadline': Adds a count.task with a date or time to complete by
 "

+ "

6.'event': Adds a task with from a date or time to another date or time
 "

+ "

7.'mark': Marks specified task as complete
 Usecase: mark 2"

+ "

8.'unmark': Marks specified task as incomplete
 Usecase: unmark 1"

+ "

9.'delete': Deletes specified task number
 Usecase: delete 3"

* Lists all the Tasks in the TaskList
* @return String for Count's UI to print

* The Mark class is used to mark the specified task as complete
* @param index int index of the Task in TaskList to mark as complete
* Marks the Task with the index of index as complete
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the index selected is out of bounds for the TaskList
return "Croak! This task is already complete!";
return "Ribbit, I have marked this task as complete:\n" + ls.getTaskList().get(this.index - 1).toString();
throw new CountException("Croak! Invalid list index chosen! Choose a number from 1 to "
+ ls.getTaskList().size() + "\nType 'help' to see correct formatting examples");
* The Remind class handles giving reminders
* whenever Count is opened and there are tasks
* stored close to the date of completion
* @param days Int for tasks with due dates within number of days
return "Croak! Looks like things are empty around here...";
String ans = "Here are the tasks in your list due within " + this.days + " days\n";
* The Save class is used to save the current TaskList as Count.txt
* @param filePath String file path the Save class will save to
* Saves the TaskList as Count.txt, overwriting any existing Count.txt
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the file creation fails
return "Croak! You don't have anything in your list to save!";
return "Ribbit, your list has been saved over at Count.txt";
* The Unmark class is used to mark the specified task as incomplete
* @param index int index of the Task in TaskList to mark as incomplete
* Marks the Task with the index of index as incomplete
* @return String for Count's UI to print
* @throws CountException if the index selected is out of bounds for the TaskList
return "Croak! This task is already incomplete!";
return "Ribbit, I have marked this task as incomplete:\n" + ls.getTaskList().get(this.index - 1).toString();
throw new CountException("Croak! Invalid list index chosen! Choose a number from 1 to "
+ ls.getTaskList().size() + "\nType 'help' to see correct formatting examples");
* CountException is the class of Exceptions thrown by Count
* It holds a message for Count to inform the user about the Exception
* @param msg String message to be printed
* IncorrectFormatException is thrown when the command given is not in a recognised format
* InvalidCommandException is thrown when the command given is not recognised
super("I'm sorry, I did not understand that, type 'help' for available commands.");
* InvalidTimelineException is thrown during Event object creation
* when the start date/time is later (or same as) than end date/time
